title: Are Faith and Doubt Compatible?
description:
Many think faith and belief are closely connected. On some views, belief is an essential part of faith. 
But what if someone's doubts keep them from belief? Is faith is possible without belief? What might that kind of faith look like? This video explores these questions and ultimate defends a credence-based faith.

title: Choosing and Controlling Beliefs: What Do Philosophers Say?
description:
This video is about doxastic voluntarism, the view that belief is under our voluntary control. First, I explain exactly what doxastic voluntarism is and why it matters. Then, I discuss why many philosophers are involuntarists, and focus on Alston's influential argument for involuntarism. Finally, I raise some worries about Alston's case and briefly discuss why I think many philosophers are wrong about whether we can choose our beliefs. 

A shoutout to my coauthor Mark Boespflug for much of this material. His website is here: https://sites.google.com/view/markboespflug/home

For more info on our grant: https://cas.stthomas.edu/departments/areas-of-study/philosophy/academic-cross-training-grant/

title: Atheism and Faith: Friends or Foes?
description:
Can atheists, who believe that God does not exist, have faith? Of course, atheists have certain kinds of faith: faith in their friends, faith in certain ideals, and faith in themselves. However, the question we’ll examine is whether atheists can have theistic faith: faith that God exists. Philosophers tend to fall on one of two extremes on this question: some, like Dan Howard-Snyder (2019), say unequivocally no; others, like Sam Lebens (forthcoming), say unequivocally yes. Spoiler: I take a middle position: I argue that atheists can have action-focused faith (faith in how they act) but not attitude-focused faith (faith in what attitudes they have).

title: Solving a Puzzle about Faith
description:
These three all seem plausible, but are inconsistent: 

1. Faith can be epistemically rational. 
2. Faith goes beyond the evidence. 
3. No epistemically rational attitude goes beyond the evidence. 

In this video I suggest a solution to the puzzle. At the end, I also briefly sketch how faith can be rational on my picture.

title: Why PERMISSIVISM is key for figuring out what to believe
description:
Is evidentialism true? 

Evidentialism is the view that evidence alone determines rational belief. Recently, several rivals to evidentialism have been defended, including pragmatic and moral encroachment, epistemic partiality, and practical and moral reasons for belief. Call these rivals “impurist” views. While impurist views have both compelling cases and interesting arguments in their favor, they also face a number of serious challenges. In this paper, I explain three of the most important challenges to impurism. Then I argue that, by embracing epistemic permissivism, impurists can hold onto what’s central to their views while dealing with all three of these challenges. Finally, I suggest that the evidentialist should also embrace permissivism, as it helps them better respond to the most compelling considerations in favor of impurism. 

Download my handout here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Handout.pdf

For an introductory video to evidentialism, see here: https://youtu.be/ZgJ3hDk0-V0

title: A New Version of Pascal's Wager
description:
Imagine you had an unlimited amount of time to ask an omniscient being anything you wanted. The potential epistemic benefits would be enormous, if not infinite: endless pieces of significant knowledge/true belief/justified belief. I argue that considerations like these point to an epistemic version of Pascal’s wager. More specifically, I show how, on an epistemic consequentialist framework, there is epistemic reason to believe in God. I compare and contrast the epistemic wager with the traditional wager, and argue that the epistemic version has several notable advantages.

This talk was given at Ryerson University in December 2019.

title: Believing with Low Confidence Supports Dualism
description:
We call attention to certain cases of epistemic akrasia, arguing that they support belief-credence dualism. Belief-credence dualism is the view that belief and credence are irreducible, equally fundamental attitudes. Consider the case of an agent who believes p, has low credence in p, and thus believes that they shouldn’t believe p. We argue that dualists, as opposed to belief-firsters (who say credence reduces to belief) and credence-firsters (who say belief reduces to credence) can best explain features of akratic cases, including the observation that akratic beliefs seem to be held despite possessing a defeater for those beliefs, and that, in akratic cases, one can simultaneously believe and have low confidence in the very same proposition.

This talk was given with Peter Tan at the Pacific APA in April 2019, with comments by Andrew Moon.

This paper, coauthored with Peter Tan (https://sites.google.com/site/petertanphilosophy/) is forthcoming in Philosophy and Phenomenological Research. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACEAA-5

title: Epistemic Permissivism and Pascal's Wager
description:
Pascal's wager is a pragmatic argument for belief in God. The basic idea is that believing in God has significant benefits, and these benefits aren’t available for the unbeliever. Thus, one should believe in God. 

This raises several questions. Can we take Pascal's wager? Do we have the right kind of control over our beliefs? And even if we can take it, should we? Shouldn't our beliefs be based on evidence, not on the potential benefits of believing? 

In this talk, I argue that if a view in epistemology called epistemic permissivism is true, then taking Pascal's wager is both possible and rational. Epistemic permissivism is the thesis that the evidence can rationally permit more than one attitude toward a proposition. First, I argue that if permissivism is true, then permissivism is true about theistic belief. Then, I show how epistemic permissivism about theistic belief dispels two objections to Pascal’s wager: the objection that wagering is impossible, and the objection that wagering is epistemically impermissible.

This talk was given at the Evangelical Philosophical Society in November 2018. 

This paper is now forthcoming in Erkenntnis. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACAPD-9

title: What Makes a Commitment Rational?
description:
Completing grad school, picking up a new instrument, getting in shape, marriage, and religious commitment all require the ability to keep a commitment over time. What makes these kinds of commitments rational? When should we give them up? 

In this talk, I examine three attitudes: belief, faith, and hope. I argue that all three attitudes can play the same role in rational commitment. First, I explain two models of rational action—the decision-theory model and the belief-desire model. Both models entail there are two components of rational action: an epistemic component and a conative component. Then, using this framework, I show how belief, faith, and hope that p can all make it rational to accept, or act as if, p. I conclude by showing how my picture can explain how action-oriented commitments can be rational over time, both in the face of counterevidence and in the face of waning affections.

This paper was presented at the World Congress of Philosophy in August 2018.

This paper was published in Mind. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACBFA

title: Why Credences Aren't Beliefs
description:
What are credences? On the belief-first view, credences are probability-beliefs. Andrew Moon and I wrote a paper responding to some objections to the belief-first view. (See here: https://youtu.be/q_DJCfkGjfU). However, I don't ultimately hold the view, and this talk explains one reason why.

Here, I argue that the belief-first view cannot account for agents who have credences in propositions they barely comprehend. I conclude that, however credences differ from beliefs, they do not differ in virtue of adding additional content to the believed proposition.

This talk was given at the Australian Catholic University in November 2019.

This paper is forthcoming in the Australasian Journal of Philosophy. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACWCA-2

title: What is Epistemic Paternalism? Is it Justified?
description:
Epistemic paternalism is the practice of interfering with someone’s inquiry, without their consent, for their own epistemic good. In this chapter, I explore the relationship between epistemic paternalism and two other epistemological theses: epistemic permissivism and standpoint epistemology. I argue that examining this relationship is fruitful because it sheds light on a series of cases in which epistemic paternalism is unjustified and brings out notable similarities between epistemic permissivism and standpoint epistemology.

This talk was given at Australian National University in September 2019. 

The paper is now published in a book titled _Epistemic Paternalism Reconsidered: Conceptions, Justifications, and Implications_. You can download the paper for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACEPE-2

title: Believing with Low Confidence: Is it Possible? Rational?
description:
We believe, withhold belief, and disbelief things. We also have various levels of credence (or confidence) in things. How do these attitudes related to each other? How tightly connected are they? 

Much of the literature on the relationship between belief and credence has focused on the reduction question: that is, whether either belief or credence reduces to the other. This debate, while important, only scratches the surface of the belief-credence connection. Even on the anti-reductive dualist view, belief and credence could still be very tightly connected. Here, I explore questions about the belief-credence connection that go beyond reduction. This paper is dedicated to what I call the independence question: just how independent are belief and credence? I look at this question from two angles: a descriptive one (as a psychological matter, how much can belief and credence come apart?) and a normative one (for a rational agent, how closely connected are belief and credence?) Ultimately, I suggest that the two attitudes are more independent than one might think.

This talk was given at the Australian National University in October 2019. 

This paper is now forthcoming in Philosophical Issues. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACOTI-2

title: Pascal's Wager: Answering the Most Common Questions
description:
Pascal's wager is an argument that you should bet, or wager, on God because of what’s at stake: you have lots to gain and not much to lose. Here, I answer some of the most common questions about Pascal's wager, such as:

What is involved in the epistemic approach to God's existence?
Does Pascal's wager conflict with evidentialism? 
What if I don't believe in hell?
Does taking Pascal's wager involve bad motives?

title: Are Credences Just Beliefs about Probability?
description:
Credences are subjective probabilities that measure one's confidence level in some proposition. For example, I have a 0.9 credence it will rain tomorrow, a 0.5 credence this coin will land heads, and a credence of 0 that 1+1=3. But what are credences? On the belief-first view, they are beliefs about probabilities.

This paper explains and defends a belief-first view of the relationship between belief and credence. On this view, credences are a species of beliefs, and the degree of credence is determined by the content of what is believed. We begin by developing what we take to be the most plausible belief-first view. Then, we offer several arguments for it. Finally, we show how it can resist objections that have been raised to belief-first views. We conclude that the belief-first view is more plausible than many have previously supposed.

This talk was given at the Degrees of Belief Conference at the University of Leeds with Andrew Moon (https://andrewymoon.wordpress.com/). 

This paper, coauthored with Andrew Moon, is now published in the Canadian Journal of Philosophy. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/MOOCAB-3

title: A Permissivist Response to Religious Disagreement
description:
What is permissivism? Can you be a permissivist and an evidentialist? What does permissivism say about religious disagreement? 

Permissivism is the thesis that, for some body of evidence and a proposition p, there is more than one rational doxastic attitude any agent with that evidence can take toward p. Proponents of uniqueness deny permissivism, maintaining that every body of evidence always determines a single rational doxastic attitude. In this paper, we explore the debate between permissivism and uniqueness about evidence, outlining some of the major arguments on each side. We then consider how permissivism can be understood as an underdetermination thesis, and show how this moves the debate forward in fruitful ways: in distinguishing between different types of permissivism, in dispelling classic objections to permissivism, and in shedding light on the relationship between permissivism and evidentialism.

This paper was presented at the Openmindedness Conference in April 2018 with Margaret Turnbull (https://margaretturnbull.weebly.com/) 

This paper, co-authored with with Margaret Turnbull, is forthcoming in the Routledge Handbook of the Philosophy of Evidence. You can download it for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACPUA

title: Can Belief-Credence Dualism Save Evidentialism?
description:
Belief-credence dualism is the view that we have both beliefs and credences and neither attitude is reducible to the other. Pragmatic encroachment is the view that practical stakes can affect the epistemic rationality of states like knowledge or justified belief. In this paper, I argue that dualism offers a unique explanation of pragmatic encroachment cases, which vindicates evidentialism. 

First, I explain pragmatic encroachment and what motivates it. Then, I explain dualism and outline a particular argument for dualism. Finally, I show how dualism can explain the intuitions that underlie pragmatic encroachment. My basic proposal is that in high-stakes cases, it is not that one cannot rationally believe that p; instead, one ought not to rely on one's belief that p. One should rather rely on one's credence in p. I conclude that we need not commit ourselves to pragmatic encroachment in order to explain the intuitiveness of the cases that motivate it.

This talk was given at the Central APA in February 2019, with comments by Rima Basu.

This paper is now published in The Philosophical Quarterly. You can download this paper for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACHBD

title: Does Faith Require Desire?
description:
When it comes to theistic faith, philosophers of religion have mostly focused on the role of counterevidence: To what extent can faith co-exist with counterevidence? When does counterevidence render faith irrational? However, counterevidence isn’t the only threat to the rationality of faith. This paper focuses on a second component of faith, that faith involves desire. This has important connections to the axiology of theism—the question of whether God’s existence would be a good thing. Pro-theists say yes, and anti-theists say no. Bringing the rationality of faith and the axiology of theism into contact raises a host of interesting issues that merit further exploration, including whether faith entails desire, faith’s conative resilience, whether having faith requires one to take a stand on the axiology of theism, and ways that anti-theism may threaten the rationality of faith.

Handout available here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/Handout.pdf

title: A Defense of Intrapersonal Belief Permissivism
description:
Permissivism is the view that there are evidential situations that rationally permit more than one attitude toward a proposition. In this paper, I argue for Intrapersonal Belief Permissivism: that there are evidential situations in which a single agent can rationally adopt more than one belief-attitude toward a proposition. I give two positive arguments for IaBP; the first involves epistemic supererogation and the second involves doubt. Then, I should how these arguments give intrapersonal permissivists a distinct response to the toggling objection. I conclude that IaBP is a view that philosophers should take seriously.

This talk was given at the Central APA in February 2018, with comments by Max Hayward.

This paper is now published in Episteme. You can download the paper for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACADO-8

Applied Ethics: An Impartial Introduction, by Elizabeth Jackson, Tyron Goldschmidt, Dustin Crummett, Rebecca Chan (Hackett)

https://philpapers.org/rec/GOLAE-2

This book is an impartial introduction to applied ethics. We focus on six popular and controversial topics: abortion, the environment, animals, poverty, punishment, and disability. We cover three chapters per topic, and each chapter is devoted to a famous or influential argument on the topic. After we present an influential argument in premise-conclusion form, we then consider objections to the argument, and replies to the objections. The book is impartial, and set up in order to equip the reader to make up her own mind about the controversial topics covered. Basically, we are trying to present the best arguments for each position, but not convince you of any particular view.

title: Should we want God to exist?
description:
Should we want God to exist? This is the central question in the axiology of theism. Pro-theists say that God’s existence would be a good thing, because if God exists, there is ultimate cosmic justice, human lives are meaningful, and no evil is gratuitous. Anti-theists say that God existence would be a bad thing, because if God’s exists, this invades our privacy, renders morality incoherent, and makes some lives meaningless and absurd. However, little work has been done on the epistemic axiology of theism. This paper seeks to fill that gap and answer the question: would God’s existence be an epistemically good thing? After a brief overview of the main theories of epistemic value, I explore considerations both in favor of epistemic pro-theism and epistemic anti-theism, and ultimately conclude in favor of epistemic pro-theism.

I presented this paper at the Princeton Philosophy of Religion Incubator Conference (May 2021). 

Handout available here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Handout.pdf

title: Can Taking Pascal's Wager Demonstrate Faith?
description:
Is taking Pascal's wager selfish? In this video, I argue that the answer is no—one can take Pascal's wager with good motives. Further, I argue that taking Pascal's wager can demonstrate either faith or hope. The person of faith and the wagerer have several things in common, including a commitment to God and positive cognitive and conative attitudes toward God’s existence. I also argue that if one’s credences in theism are too low to have faith, the wagerer can still hope that God exists, another commitment-justifying theological virtue. I consider two upshots of my argument, including how my picture provides responses to common objections to Pascal’s wager.

I presented this paper in the Society of Christian Philosophers (SCP) session at the 2021 Pacific Meeting of the American Philosophical Association. Thanks to Anne Jeffrey for her great comments! (Learn more about Anne here: https://www.annejeffrey.com).

Handout available here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/APA-handout.pdf

A draft of the paper is available here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACFTP-2

title: Practical Ways to Disagree Well (with Sawyer Bullock)
description:
In this video, Sawyer Bullock interviews me about having discussions about controversial issues. I share three tips for disagreeing more productively. 

0:00 Intro
4:54 Tip 1: Realize there are good arguments for positions you disagree with, and bad arguments for positions you agree with. 
8:20 Tip 2: Acknowledge that, even if you both can’t be right, you can both be rational.
13:05 Tip 3: Remember the goal of such discussions is finding the truth, not winning a debate.

title: Responding to Three Objections to Pascal's Wager
description:
Pascal's wager is an argument that you should believe in God, because you have a lot to gain by believing and a lot to lose by not believing. In this video, I defend Pascal's wager against three objections: (1) The many-gods objection; (2) the impossibility objection, and (3) the irrationality objection. 

This talk is based on two papers of mine: 

Salvaging Pascal's wager: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACSPW
Epistemic Permissivism and Pascal's wager: (currently under review; email me for a draft) 

This talk was presented to the Talbot philosophy department on March 12, 2021. Thanks to Anthony Rowden for inviting me, and for designing the awesome thumbnail!

title: How to Tell WHAT Argument Someone is Making
description:
This video is about argument reconstruction. Once you've identified that someone is making an argument, how do you know what argument the author is making?

We discuss why we reconstruct arguments in standard form. Then we discuss the three steps of argument reconstruction: identifying the conclusion, identifying the premises, and applying the principles of charity and faithfulness. Finally, we talk about cheap validity: the idea that it's always possible to make any invalid argument valid by adding a linking premise. 

Much of the material from this video is taken from Feldman's Reason and Argument, chapter 5.

title: Three Kinds of Good Arguments
description:
This video is about what makes a valid argument a good one. First, we discuss why a valid argument can be a bad argument. Then, we discuss three ways an argument can be good: it has true premises (so it is sound), it has premises that are rational to believe (so it is strong), and it has premises that are known to be true. We talk about limitations of each kind of argument. 

I recommend reviewing the material from this video first: https://youtu.be/yGECoBlGHs8

Here is a video about knowledge: https://youtu.be/HI_q7RUjQ6I

title: Why Playing Pretend Can Make You A Good Philosopher
description:
This video is about valid and invalid arguments. First, we discuss the value of standard form arguments. Then, we see two ways an argument can go wrong: if it has a false premise, or if the conclusion doesn't follow from the premises. We discuss the definition of validity and how it is similar to playing pretend. Then, we cover six general valid argument forms and two general invalid argument forms. We close with three tips for discovered validity and invalidity, and finally a distinction between two kinds of validity. Much of the content from the video is taken from Feldman's _Reason and Argument_, chapter 3.

title: Should We Believe Controversial Philosophical Theories?
description:
What attitude should philosophers take toward their favorite philosophical theories? I argue that the answer is belief and middling to low credence. I begin by discussing why disagreement has motivated many to say philosophers cannot rationally believe their theories, and I explain why the argument from disagreement does not ultimately establish this. Then, I motivate my view in three ways: the first concerns roles for belief and credence, the second provides other cases of rational belief and middling to low credence, and the final explains why believing one’s philosophical theories is superior to endorsing them. I close by discussing implications my view has for the Lockean thesis, the view that there is an important connection between rational belief and rational credence. 

I presented this paper in the "Belief and Credence" session at the 2021 Eastern Meeting of the American Philosophical Association.

Handout available here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/APA-handout.pdf

title: Belief, Confidence, and Faith
description:
This video explores how faith could be rational but nonetheless go beyond the evidence. First, we talk about the puzzle of faith and reason. Then, we examine two attitudes: belief and confidence, and we see how evidence can change our confidence without changing our beliefs. Then, we see how this picture enables faith to remain steadfast, even as we get evidence that moves our confidence up and down. 

For a popular-level summary of this video in written form, see here: http://liz-jackson.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/How-Can-Faith-Go-Beyond-the-Evidence-and-Still-Be-Rational.pdf

This paper is based on a paper of mine published in Religious Studies, available here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACBCA.

title: Can Belief in God Be Rational Without Arguments?
description:
This video is about reformed epistemology, the thesis that belief in God can be rational without arguments. First, we discuss an argument that religious belief is irrational. Then, we talk about 4 kinds of beliefs: rational, irrational, basic, and non-basic. Then we look at a number of reasons to think that a belief can be rational, even if it isn't based on an argument. Finally, we apply this reasoning to belief that God exists, and discuss why the existence of a sensus divinitatis provides reason to think that belief in God can be rational without arguments. 

For a longer defense of reformed epistemology, see here: https://youtu.be/ZXVTD52ufDA.

For a scholarly paper on recent work in reformed epistemology, see here: https://philpapers.org/rec/MOORWI-2.

title: Should You Always Follow the Evidence?
description:
This video is about a theory in epistemology called evidentialism. Evidentialism is the view that what we should believe is determined only by our evidence. We then discuss three recently challenges to evidentialism: epistemic partiality, moral encroachment, and beneficial beliefs. We conclude by examining some ways that an evidentialist might respond to these challenges.

title: Should You Take Their Word For It?
description:
This video is about the epistemology of testimony. First, we compare and contrast traditional and social epistemology. Then, we discuss reasons to think that we rely on testimony all the time. Next, we talk about three views in the epistemology of testimony: testimony skepticism, reductionism, and anti-reductionism. Finally, we look at two factors to consider when deciding who to trust, and why some philosophers think that knowing from testimony is limited in key ways.

For more about defeaters: https://youtu.be/RNzPcTDNKpw

title: Dilemmas, Disagreement, and Dualism
description:
In this video, I defend my view of disagreement: conciliationism about credence and steadfastness about belief. I present for about 10 minutes, then there is 5 minutes of Q&A. This was originally presented at the Social (Distance) Epistemology workshop on August 21, 2020. 

Download paper here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACDDA-2

Abstract of paper: This paper introduces and motivates a solution to a dilemma from peer disagreement. Following Buchak (2021), I argue that peer disagreement puts us in an epistemic dilemma: there is reason to think that our opinions should both change and not change when we encounter disagreement with our epistemic peers. I argue that we can solve this dilemma by changing our credences, but not our beliefs in response to disagreement. I explain how my view solves the dilemma in question, and then offer two additional arguments for it: one related to contents and attitudes, and another related to epistemic peerhood.

title: The Relationship Between Belief and Credence
description:
This is a summary of my paper, titled "The Relationship Between Belief and Credence," which has just been published in Philosophy Compass. You can download and read the paper for free here: https://philpapers.org/rec/JACTRB-5

Main concepts/definitons:

The ontological question: do both belief and credence exist? 

Belief-eliminitivism: beliefs don’t exist.
Credal-eliminativism: credences don’t exist.

The reduction question: Is one attitude more metaphysically fundamental?

Credence-first view: credence is more fundamental than belief. 
Belief-first view: belief is more fundamental than credence. 
Dualism: belief and credence are equally fundamental.

Lockean Thesis: S ought to believe p iff S has a rational high credence in p.
